Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: Collaborative Research: I/UCRC for Surveillance Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative project will support the planning activities for adding two new sites to the existing NSF I/UCRC Center for Surveillance Research (CSR), which is currently composed of Wright State University and Ohio State University (both of which are in Phase 2 effective September 2015). A successful execution of this project will lead to addition of these two new sites to the Center for Surveillance Research, where students and faculty will be working on industrial relevant applied research problems that could generate US Jobs in this unique area, and help with the industrial job placement of students working on Center projects. The fundamental intellectual issues addressed by these new sites will have immediate application in application domains including medical imaging, transportation, and law enforcement.

The core objective of the CSR I/UCRC center has been the development of algorithms for sensor signal and image exploitation, and the development of means to predict the performance and reliability of these algorithms under a variety of operating conditions. Proposed new sites at the University of Kansas and the University of Oklahoma will extend the center's core technologies into weather radar, waveform optimization and spectrum usage, multi-function systems, space-based sensing, and maritime applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The planning grant enabled a successful planning meeting to be held at the University of Oklahoma in February 2016 where prospective affiliate organizations from industry and government were allowed to participate and, in so doing, learn how the IUCRC project selection and feedback process are conducted. The purpose in the University of Kansas and University of Oklahoma joining the Center for Surveillance Research (CSR) is to broaden the scope to include greater experimental capabilities as well as particular expertise in weather radar, scientific remote sensing, multi-function systems, radar/communication spectrum engineering and sharing, and waveform diversity and design.

Specifically, the experimental component will permit the center to address the challenges involved with the development of theoretical structures that closely match realistic sensor phenomenology and operation. Further, while the primary application, as determined by the industry and government affiliates involves, will be upon defense and security applications, the center will have a broader impact on medical imaging, transportation, and emerging civil applications (e.g. the Google hand gesture radar). Finally, this student-centric activity will facilitate the training of the next generation of innovators in sensor technologies and interpretation of sensor data, which is particularly important given the growing shortage of sensor experts with the ability to work in the defense sector.
